summary: This paper presents a detailed analysis of the star GHV-62024, an O6.5 IIIf star in the low-metallicity galaxy IC1613, using the FASTWIND model. It examines the star's wind properties and evolutionary status, finding that the star follows the expected wind momentum-luminosity relationship (WLR) for its metallicity, but with a high value for the exponent of the wind velocity law, β. The findings challenge and refine aspects of the theory of radiatively driven winds at low metallicities.
relationships: The wind momentum-luminosity relationship (WLR) depends almost solely on the stellar luminosity and metallicity.
The mass-loss rate and the exponent of the velocity law, β, are interdependent and crucial for fitting the He II 4686 line profile.
The terminal wind velocity, Vinf, and the mass-loss rate, Mdot, are related through the Q-parameter.
variables: β: Exponent of the wind velocity law
Q: A parameter that determines the net wind emission
T: Effective temperature of the star
key_ideas: The star GHV-62024 follows the average WLR expected for its metallicity, suggesting the applicability of radiatively driven wind theory at low metallicities.
A high value of β (2.0) was necessary to fit the emission profile of He II 4686, indicating a slower acceleration in the inner wind.
The findings suggest that fast rotation and viewing angle may affect the observed properties of stellar winds, including the exponent β of the wind velocity law.
The study highlights the importance of accurate measurements of wind properties and metallicity in understanding stellar evolution in low-metallicity environments.
